description.narrative: The goal of the project is to assist the country in mainstreaming and integration of climate change consideration into national and sectorial development policies by providing continuity to the institutional and technical capacity strengthening process.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative: Indicator 1: Quality of MRV Systems* Indicator 2: Status of Convention obligations on reporting, including mitigation contribution Indicator 3: Qualitative Assessment of Institutional Capacity for Transparency-Related Activities** Indicator 4: Number of direct project beneficiaries disaggregated by gender as co-benefit of GEF investment

comment.narrative: [1] Measurement systems are strong for a limited set of activities and periodically report on key GHG related indicators i.e. mainstreamed into the activity implementation; reporting is improved through few pathways but limited audience and formats; verification limited.[indicator 1 and indicator 3] [2] Initial Nationaly Determined Contributions, Third National Communication and Second Biennial Update Report submitted.[indicator 2] [3] Measurement systems are in place, but data is of poor quality and/or methodologies are not very robust; reporting is done only on request or to limited audience or partially; verification is not there. [indicator 1 and indicator 3] [4] 29 project beneficiaries, out of which 12 are women [indicator 4]

The CBIT project has supported addressing two major issues related to establishment of the type of continuous MRV that is necessary for an enhanced transparency framework: lack of formalized arrangements for the preparation of country reporting on climate change to the UNFCCC and the Paris Agreement and limited organizational capacity within Macedonian institutions to collect, analyze, report, and utilize data related to climate change.[1.2] [3.2] An administrative capacity survey has been administered, and the findings will be used to specify job profiles and tasks for climate MRV/transparency positions at MOEPP and other agencies. The administrative capacity survey has also developed cost estimates for a functional climate change transparency/MRV team in order to provide the government with this information. [1.2] The project also carried out a survey on individual capacity needs and commissioned a Capacity and Training Needs Assessment for Transparency. The assessment report used the survey feedback from 26 climate change stakeholders in the country to assess current capacity needs related to meeting monitoring, reporting, and verification (MRV) requirements under Article 13 of the Paris Agreement, identifying areas where training and capacity strengthening were needed, and providing recommendations on the structure and content of these activities. These results were presented in a webinar. The findings were used to develop a detailed training plan for 2020 and 2021, which covers the suggested timing, target group, content, goal and provider of various training and capacity strengthening measures under the CBIT project. The training plan for 2020 has been fully implemented. [1.3] The project team has developed toolkits on MRV for the national GHG inventory and for GHG mitigation for the AFOLU sector, and it has held a series of webinars to familiarize stakeholders with these tools and to answer questions.[1.3] [3.2] Legal baseline for the MRV work has been set in the Law of Climate Action.[2.2] The project has provided expertise and support for mainstreaming climate change into sectoral policies/legislation in the areas of energy, energy efficiency, renewables, transport, gender, spatial planning, waste, green jobs and implementation of Agenda 2030 and the Sustainable Development Goals.[2.3] The National Network of Climate Change Practitioners is functional and engaged in project activities. Project team organized a series of 26 online webinars and trainings during the COVID lockdown period that were well attended and generated active discussion. [3.2] Training modules for key administrative stakeholders on gender and climate change/environment have also been developed and are publicly available on the national climate change platform www.klimatskipromeni.mk.[4.2]

[1.4] MRV platform designed and developed. [1.5] Protocol developed for providing support to government ministries and agencies on climate transparency issues upon request. [2.4]Expert networks relevant to climate change established. [3.3] The 2021 training plan on transparency activities implemented. [4.3] At least two IT tools for visualization and communication of climate change data developed

The MRV platform has been designed to meet the enhanced transparency requirements as defined in Article 13 of the Paris Agreement. The platfrom enables efficient coordination, engagement and information necessary for use in compiling Macedonian regular UNFCCC reports and for actions presented in the enhanced NDC.. Specifically, the MRV platform provides support compliance with monitoring and reporting under the: Modalities, Procedures and Guidelines (MPGs) for reporting under the Paris Agreement; Requirements of the European Union (EU) regarding the Regulation on the mechanism for monitoring and reporting greenhouse gas emissions and for reporting other information at national and Union level relevant to climate change and the Regulation on the Governance of the Energy Union and Climate Action; Other monitoring and reporting purpose. Moreover, a rulebook has been drafted to regulate the minimum requirements, as well as the manner of management and maintenance of the electronic platform for exchange and submission of data on climate action. The rulebook has been submitted to the Ministry of Environment and Physical Planning for adoption [1.4]
A protocol has been developed for providing “on-call” support (provided by the Climate change unit) to other sectoral ministries and government agencies as needed. This protocol is described in details in the Climate Chnage Institutional Capacity Assessment, developed within the project [1.5]
Expert networks relevant to climate change established for all IPCC sectors.In addition, the project has organized a network of 319 persons working in the field of gender and climate change at the national and local administrative level (61% of the network participants are women). [2.4]
The 2021 training plan on transparency activities has been fully implemented. Training modules for key civil servants on various thematic areas have been developed and are publicly available on the national climate change platform https://www.klimatskipromeni.mk/#/index/main. Additionally, virtual study tour has been implemented to enable sharing knowledge between GHG inventory developers in Czech Republic and Macedonia [3.3]
IT tools for visualization and communication of climate change data developed: GIS tool for mainstreaming climate change in spatial and urban planning and national climate change platform sccessible for persons with visual and hearing impairment [4.3]

The project document was approved by the GEF in March 2019. The Project document was signed in June 2019. The project inception workshop took place on 17 September 2019 with the participation of 58 relevant stakeholders from 22 Institutions, 75 % of them woman. The project implementation modality remains the same as agreed at the project approval stage. The Project Results Framework validated by the relevant parties. [1.1]
The legal bases for establishment of the domestic Measurement, Reporting and Verification arrangements has been closely supported through close cooperation with the ongoing IPA funded project for development of Law and Strategy on Climate Action. [2.1]
Support has been provided in development of the Voluntary National review of the Macedonian progress in implementation of the SDGs and setting the national indicator MRV framework (guided by the UN RC Office and the Cabinet of the Deputy President of the Government in charge of economic affairs and coordination of economic departments). [2.1]
Additionally, first important step towards climate transparency has been made by opening all existing climate change relevant data from the MOEPP and City of Skopje on the national open data portal. [2.1]
A unit at MOEPP established to oversee MRV issues related to climate change reporting on national and international commitments. The unit comprises five junior associates: 2 engineers, 1 economist, 1 architect and 1 legal associate. The positions of the team have been fully incorporated with the functional specification of the Ministry of Environment and Physical Planning. [3.1]
The Network on national practitioners on climate change that was established (app, 60 participants from 20 governmental institutions). This network shall be the overarching niche to engage key ministries and sub-national authorities to coordinate and harmonize inputs and enhance climate action, but also to ensure that transparency activities are aligned with country priorities. This should result in broad ownership of the MRV framework and mobilizing society as a whole around the climate goals stipulated in the Macedonian NDC. [3.1]
The linkages between gender and climate change have gained high political support, as a result of UNDP efforts to demonstrate that effective and ambitious climate action goes hand in hand with gender (elaborated 5 country specific examples on gender and climate change, developed training programme on gender and climate change for governmental and municipal institutions, first country in the region to held public debate in the Macedonian Parliament in front of 60 representatives of politicians, parliament members, international organizations, municipalities, ministries, commissions, donor community etc.). [4.1]
